questions.question: Your handwriting is ……………….. good, but you can improve it.
questions.description:
If something is fairly good, it is not very good. It is satisfactory. 
Fairly does not suggest a very high degree.

questions.question: He is ………………………….. tall. He should be able to join the basketball team.
questions.description: If he is quite or rather tall, then height will not be an issue at all.

questions.question: My room looks ……………………….. neat and tidy. I don’t have to clean it for at least a week.
questions.description: Either quite or rather can be used here. Both of them express a higher degree than fairly.

questions.question: The exam was ……………………. difficult. I don’t think that I will pass.
questions.description: Either quite or rather can be used here.

questions.question: His books are ………………………….. difficult to understand. I don’t enjoy reading them at all.
questions.description: Rather and quite indicate a very high degree.

questions.question: She can speak German ………………….. fluently. People often think she is German.
questions.description: Rather and quite indicate a very high degree.

questions.question: It is ……………………… foolish of you to behave like that.
Her speeches are ………………………… interesting. I make it a point to listen to them.
questions.description: Rather suggests a very higher degree than fairly.

questions.question: Our team’s performance was ……………………….. a disappointment.
questions.description: Both quite and rather can modify nouns and verbs.

questions.question: I was …………………………. disappointed with my results.
questions.description: If you are quite disappointed, then you are really disappointed.

questions.question: You had better not go out now. It is ………………………….. cold.
questions.description: All of these expressions suggest very high degrees of something.
